chapterTitle: Return, Risk, and The Security Market Line

columns.text: In this exercise, we are asked to determine the portfolio's expected return, variance, and standard deviation.

The **expected return** is the net income or loss that an investor predicts on investments given known interest rates.

The **variance** of investment's return quantifies how each amount in the series of investments deviates from average and consequently from another value in the group.

The **standard deviation** is a statistical measure of the distribution of values around the mean of a population. This is the variance's square root.

Let's first identify the given amounts in the problem: 


| | Amount$\hspace{5pt}$| 
|:--|--:| 
|Boom: ||
|Probability return | 10% | 
|Stock A's rate of return |35%|
|Stock B's rate of return |40%|
|Stock C's rate of return |27%|
|Good: ||
|Probability return | 60% | 
|Stock A's rate of return |16%|
|Stock B's rate of return |17%|
|Stock C's rate of return |8%|
|Poor: ||
|Probability return |25%|
|Stock A's rate of return |-1%|
|Stock B's rate of return |-3%|
|Stock C's rate of return |-4%|
|Bust: ||
|Probability return |5%|
|Stock A's rate of return |-12%|
|Stock B's rate of return |-18%|
|Stock C's rate of return |-9%|

## A. 

First, let us compute the expected return of each state of the economy. This is calculated by multiplying the given percentages by the stock's rate of return. Let us first compute the expected return during Boom. 

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Expected return, Boom}&= {\text{(30\% $\times$ 35\%) + (40\% $\times$ 40\%) + (30\% $\times$ 27\%)}}\\
&={\text{10.50\% + 16\% + 8.10\%}}\\
&= {\textbf{34.60\%}}
\end{aligned}$$

**The expected return during Boom is 34.60%.**

Then, we also need to compute the expected return during good state of economy. This is computed as follows: 

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Expected return, Good}&= {\text{(30\% $\times$ 16\%) + (40\% $\times$ 17\%) + (30\% $\times$ 8\%)}}\\
&={\text{4.80\%  + 6.80\% + 2.40\%}}\\
&= {\textbf{14.00\%}}
\end{aligned}$$

**The expected return during a good state of the economy is 14.00%.**

Next, let us compute the expected return during poor state of economy. This is computed as follows: 

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Expected return, Poor}&= {\text{(30\% $\times$ -1\%) + (40\% $\times$ -3\%) + (30\% $\times$ -4\%)}}\\
&={\text{-0.3\% - 1.20\% - 1.20\%}}\\
&= {\textbf{-2.70\%}}
\end{aligned}$$

**The expected return during a poor state of the economy is -2.70%.**

Then, let us compute the expected return during bust state of economy. This is computed as follows: 

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Expected return, Bust}&= {\text{(30\% $\times$ -12\%) + (40\% $\times$ -18\%) + (30\% $\times$ -9\%)}}\\
&={\text{-3.60\% - 7.20\% - 2.70\%}}\\
&= {\textbf{-13.50\%}}
\end{aligned}$$

**The expected return during a bust state of the economy is -13.50%.**

## B. 

The variance of the stock's return is computed as follows: 


$$\begin{aligned}
\text{V}&={\sum_\text{}} {\text{PR $\times$(R - AR)}^\text{ 2}}
\end{aligned}$$

Where: \
PR = Probability return\
T = Year\
R = Realized return \
V = Variance

Let us compute the variance of the poprtfolio using the formula from step 9. This is computed as follows: 

$$\begin{array}{l}
\text{V}=  {\text{[10\% $\times$ (34.60\% - 10.50\%)}^\text{ 2}}{{]}} + {\text{[60\% $\times$ (14\% - 10.50\%)}^\text{ 2}}{{]}}\\[5pt]
\hspace{20pt} {\text{+ [25\% $\times$ (-2.70\% - 10.50\%)}^\text{ 2}}{{]}} + {\text{[5\% $\times$ (-13.50\% - 10.50\%)}^\text{ 2}}{{]}}\\
\hspace{10pt}= {\textbf{0.0137791}}
\end{array}$$

**The variance of the portfolio is 0.0137791.**
